properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight and Saturday. Lake effect flurries off of Georgian Bay may develop this evening and persist into Saturday. Local snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are possible by Saturday afternoon. Travel is expected to be difficult at times due to poor visibility in snow and local blowing snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads and walkways may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-20T07:38:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-19T15:39:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2988948597.2021
Area: Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong wind gusts up to 100 km/h today in southwestern Alberta. Wind gusts, at times reaching 100 km/h, developed overnight and will continue through the morning. These strong winds will weaken by late this afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-20T03:06:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-19T11:07:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2679565301.2021

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected tonight and Saturday. Locally heavy snow squalls may develop off of Lake Huron this evening and persist into Saturday. Travel may be hazardous due to poor visibility in snow and blowing snow. Snowfall accumulations up to 15 cm are possible, though the shifting nature of the snow squall bands may limit accumulations over a given location. The snow squalls are expected to weaken Saturday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-20T07:37:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-19T15:38:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2866210517.2021
Area: Saugeen Shores - Kincardine - Southern Bruce County, Wingham - Blyth - Northern Huron County, Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentrations of pollutants are expected through Friday morning and will result in poor air quality, especially in metropolitan areas where pollutant emissions are more significant. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-19T21:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2021-02-19T01:24:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2702911722.2021

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls may impact the area into Friday afternoon. Travel along Highway 17 between White River and Wawa may become hazardous due to heavy snow and poor visibility. Snowfall accumulations up to 10 cm are possible, although the shifting nature of the snow bands may limit accumulations. At this point, it appears that the heaviest amounts will occur south of Highway 17. The snow squalls should move east of the region by late Friday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-20T05:13:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-19T13:14:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3206401527.2021
Area: White River - Dubreuilville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chills near minus 55 will return to Resolute tonight. Cooling temperatures and strengthening winds will bring wind chill values back into the minus 55 to minus 60 range overnight. Temperatures will moderate and winds will ease on Sunday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-20T07:24:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-19T15:25:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1545745297.2021
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Lake effect flurries off of Lake Superior will continue to affect the region today. Travel along Highway 17 between White River and Wawa may become difficult at times due to poor visibility in snow and local blowing snow. Snowfall accumulations up to 10 cm are possible with the highest amounts expected south of Highway 17. The snow squalls should move east of the region this evening. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A pacific frontal system is generating snow over the Kitimat area. The snow will change to rain showers this morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls continue today. Locally heavy snow squalls continue to affect the region today. Travel along Highway 17 between Wawa and Agawa Bay may become hazardous due to poor visibility in snow and blowing snow. Additional snowfall amounts of up to 15 cm are possible today. The snow squalls are expected to move south of the region this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-20T07:59:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-19T16:29:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2769680663.2021
Area: Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow tonight and Saturday. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locations: most of Nova Scotia, including Halifax Metro. Time span: this evening until late Saturday. Remarks: Snow will begin spreading across western Nova Scotia early this evening and will spread eastward across the province tonight, reaching Cape Breton by early Saturday morning. The snow will taper to flurries during the day Saturday over western areas and Saturday evening over eastern areas. The highest amounts of near 15 cm of snow will likely fall along the Atlantic coast and also in onshore northeasterly winds over Pictou and Antigonish counties. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-20T11:32:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-19T19:33:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1912011775.2021
